name: Digestive Enzymes
summary: Digestive enzyme supplements contain naturally occurring proteins such as amylase, protease, and lipase that help break down carbohydrates, proteins, and fats, and are sometimes used to improve gastrointestinal comfort and nutrient absorption.
description: Digestive enzymes are substances produced in the pancreas, stomach, and small intestine, as well as derived from plants (e.g., papain, bromelain) and microbial sources. Supplementation is intended to support digestion in individuals with enzyme insufficiency or functional gastrointestinal issues. While primarily used for digestive health, improved nutrient absorption and reduced gut inflammation may have downstream effects on mental health, given the gut-brain axis.

metadata.natural_source: Pancreatic extracts, plant sources (papaya, pineapple), microbial fermentation
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved as a drug)

off_label_uses: Support for nutrient absorption in malabsorption conditions
contraindications: Allergy to specific enzyme sources (e.g., pork-derived enzymes, papaya, pineapple)

items: General digestive support for bloating and indigestion

sections.text: Digestive enzymes catalyze the breakdown of macronutrients: amylases digest carbohydrates, proteases digest proteins, and lipases digest fats. Plant-derived enzymes such as bromelain (from pineapple) and papain (from papaya) provide proteolytic activity and may also have mild anti-inflammatory effects.

adult.typical: 1–2 capsules with meals (varies by product and enzyme activity units)
adult.note: Prescription pancreatic enzyme products are dosed according to lipase activity (units per meal).

sections.pediatric: Variable; consult pediatrician for enzyme deficiency.

sections.text: Effects are typically noticed within days of starting supplementation, especially for bloating or maldigestion.

other: Do not exceed recommended dosages; very high doses may cause GI irritation.
Plant-based proteolytic enzymes may interact with clotting.

items.risk: Proteolytic enzymes like bromelain may increase bleeding risk

sections.pregnancy: Likely safe in standard supplemental doses; avoid high-dose proteolytic enzymes
sections.lactation: Limited data; likely safe in dietary amounts
sections.pediatrics: Use only under supervision when medically indicated
sections.geriatrics: Generally safe; may support digestion in age-related decline

sections.text: No tapering required; supplementation can be stopped abruptly.

items: Prescription pancreatic enzyme replacement (e.g., Creon) is distinct from over-the-counter digestive enzyme blends.
Some enzyme blends include herbs or betaine HCl; formulations vary widely.
Gut-brain benefits remain speculative but may relate to reduced GI inflammation and improved nutrient status.

items.label: Domínguez-Muñoz JE. Pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy: exocrine pancreatic insufficiency after gastrointestinal surgery. HPB. 2009
Klein AP. Pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy: Clinical practice guidelines. Pancreatology. 2021
